definitions.definition: an event in which a large number of people walk through a public place to express their support for something, or their disagreement with or disapproval of something:
examples: She's going on a march on Saturday in protest over the closure of the hospital.

definitions.definition: to walk somewhere quickly and in a determined way, often because you are angry:
examples: She marched into my office and demanded to know why I hadn't written my report.

definitions.definition: to walk through a public place as part of a public event to express support for something, or disagreement with or disapproval of something:
examples: Over four thousand people marched through London today to protest against the proposed new law.

definitions.definition: to walk with regular steps and keeping the body stiff, usually in a formal group of people who are all walking in the same way:
examples: The band marched through the streets.

definitions.definition: the third month of the year, after February and before April:
examples: The next meeting will be in March.
